Linelight might be the best puzzle game I've ever played.

It's as simple and minimalist as you can get, you move a glowy light along a line. Very easy to learn and control, yet satisfying and smooth. Because it's limited to just lines and lights, the puzzles are tight and elegant without visual clutter.

What elevates this game above the rest is its superb level design. There's constantly new twists and mechanics introduced, like every other puzzle game, but here they come at such a comfortable pace that they never feel exhausting or bloated. I kept wanting to go for just a few more.

And as you go along the main line path, the puzzles combine the different concepts you've learned. It's getting more difficult, but instead of overwhelming you with [b]intensity[/b], it's always intuitive and clever. It feels charming, like the game was always trying to subtly teach and guide you, rather than arrogantly challenge you.

There's no narration, no dialogue, no characters. The game stays humble, not trying to deliver any pretentious story. Yet at times it can still feel like you're experiencing a beautiful little story, told only through combining its gameplay and your input.

It's only about 2 hours to get to the end, but took me about 7 hours total to do all the optional puzzles. I love how all the secret puzzles are found within the main puzzles, always accessible but never intrusive. Still, even the 2 hour version was worth it.

Linelight is warm and inviting. It's like a cozy light that makes the surrounding darkness feel peaceful and gentle.

I'm generally a fan of abstract, minimalist puzzle games. I'll play them just to scratch that itch, even if they aren't all that noteworthy. Linelight stands head and shoulders above pretty much ANYTHING else in this category though. It has one of the most finely tuned difficulty curves I think I've ever seen, and every puzzle feels more like a conversation about an idea than an obstacle. And it's FULL of content, 8 worlds long with new ideas all the time, and a ton of secret extra-hard bonus puzzles to search out.

And if that weren't enough, what's this? Am I actually becoming emotionally invested in a game about lines? Through the use of a great soundtrack and pure game mechanics, Linelight somehow manages to evoke a melancholy story about conflict, friendship, loss, and finding purpose, in a way that something like Thomas Was Alone with its stilted, brow-beating narration never could. In all aspects it's simply a charming game that should be in any puzzle-lover's library.

Most timing difficulties are actually the result of attempting an incorrect solution.

There are 240 main puzzles and 60 optional challenge puzzles, split among 8 worlds. Each world will introduce a major new mechanism (generally a new type of "line") and start you with simple puzzles that will escalate in difficulty as you progress through the world. Later worlds will also integrate some mechanics from previous worlds to add some variety. Given the sheer number of puzzles, the general lack of repititiveness in puzzles was also refreshing. Each world ends with a "tandem" segment in which you solve puzzles in tandem with the new line type that was introduced in the given world. Solutions for these segments are generally easier, but generate a nice kineticism and build-up as you work with your "partner" in a final sprint to the finish.

The use of multiple worlds to generate new mechanics, the way the worlds build up as you play, and the terminal segments all help create diversity and break up the monotony of solving the same problem over and over again, which can be a failing of a lot of games in this genre. Altogether, these elements, with a very nice accompanying responsive score help generate a sense of flow (and even a bit of narrative force) in the game that puts Linelight a cut above the rest.

Mechanism is the core of a puzzle game. The gun in the Portal series is a mechanism, and the non-Euclidean geometry in Antichamber is also a mechanism. To decide whether a mechanism is good or not, three levels are proposed for evaluation.

[olist]
[*] Is this mechanism related to puzzle?

[olist]
[*] Is this mechanism well introduced in the progress of levels?

[olist]

[*] Is the potential or underlying usages of the mechanism flourish in the game, so that players will be surprised how could it be turned into so many variants?
[*] Is this mechanism compatible with other mechanisms in the game, leading to even more possibilities and innovation in level design? 
[/olist]

Linelight is a triumph in terms of discovery through gameplay. There's no tutorial to speak of in this game. Instead, Linelight relies on simple controls and a superb gradient of difficulty that metes out patterns and puzzles gradually. Though the puzzles can become rather complex, the elements are all introduced fairly gradually. This ensures that you learn all you need to before taking on harder challenges. This not only allows for maximum satisfaction when you successfully plot and think your way through an area, but also resulted in a number of fluid, almost unconscious solutions as I sailed through sections feeling very pleased with myself indeed.

Occasionally, when it comes to gaming's more overwrought puzzle experiences, you can sometimes almost hear the designer saying 'look how clever I am'. But the finest puzzle games find a way to allow the player to share in that feeling. Portal, for example, is a game with a brilliantly simple but gloriously clever premise at its heart. It makes us feel intelligent and buoyant when we solve the challenges. It gives us the illusion of agency in discovery, yet still wows us with its design. The same can be said of Linelight, in its own way. Here is a game that delivers moments of pure pleasure. It does so as an aesthetic experience, in the captivating construction of its worlds, and as an arty puzzler yielding precious eureka moments of fulfilment.

I suppose the saddest thing is that it has to end, and you really won't want it to. If I may offer a little advice to those of you who do get it...don't speed through it all at once. Linelight, like all puzzle games really, loses some of its magic in repeat playthroughs, even if there are extra collectibles and hidden puzzles to help prolong the game's life. The first run through will only take you a handful of hours, so savour everything that you can. There are few finer games this year so far.

Zpočátku je hratelnost jednoduchá, hra vás učí své principy a zde musím Linelight vychválit až do nebes.

Postupem času se na nejprve jednoduché hádanky nabalují další a další prvky, díky kterým bude celý tento titul celkem výzvou. Budete tu mít plošiny, spínače, klíče a zámky, urychlovače pohybu, dojde i na různé druhy čárek, z nichž má každá jiný vzorec chování (některé se pohybují samovolně, jiné jsou vázány na váš pohyb, další zase můžete přitáhnout k sobě), poté zjistíte, že můžete zvětšovat svou velikost, tvořit vlastní kopie atd. 如果你想对剧情有一点了解的话，不妨看一下这位叫Probe的朋友的理解，他和我的理解是相同的。下面就是他的评测里的内容的摘抄。

游戏的关卡数量很多，如果你对解谜游戏着迷，那就千万不要错过。而且游戏的一个大关中，地图是开放的，关卡之间互相连接，你可以先往前走，也可以后退看看之前也许漏掉了什么。这样，玩家有时就可以直接跳关，不去收集那些收集物（黄光点/宝石）。[i]当然我知道有强迫症的玩家肯定不会放过的哈哈哈~[/i]  每一大关还有隐藏的收集，这更是那些非全收集不可的玩家的福音……写到这里忘了说一点，游戏中的BGM的节奏和一些场景是配合起来的哦~因此玩起来还十分的带感。

最后，我相信这个游戏是值这个价格的。用心体会吧，说不定linelight会给你的生活添一缕光彩呢。

If someone had told me that I would feel true empathy for little bouncing specks of light on a screen after a couple hours playing a game - that I'd feel like I was running around on a playground with them, or choreographing a dance, or training them as one would a pet... I would have called them crazy. But Linelight is magical like that. It's the Journey of minimalistic puzzle games, and that is an amazing thing.

A huge part of it is how the (beautiful) music provides a counterpoint to the game mechanics: you have these "enemy" particles that you'd normally feel like you were trying to avoid or run away from, but the music reminds you that you can harness their behavior to help you out. And each "world" in the game culminates with a series of puzzles, where you use the behavior you've learned to run alongside a "partner" particle, helping it to move forward, helping it to help you to move forward... and then when you inevitably need to part ways, the music is there to underscore the bittersweet end to the partnership. And throughout it all, sound effects blend with the music seamlessly and in a harmonically pleasing way. It's a masterfully calming and thought-provoking experience, and I don't think I've seen anything like it.

Other commenters have described how the puzzles aren't the most challenging in the world, and there's not a ton of replayability. But in the context of the experience, that's okay. You're not supposed to pull your hair out, you're supposed to savor the experience. That said, I'm sure there will be speedruns if this game takes off, and eventually community level editing will increase the longevity here.

One minor gripe is that on Mac OS X, at least with my configuration, there were some screen tearing glitches, and some of the lighting effects could use some dithering to reduce visible "rings" where the color gradient changes. But these are minor, and they don't really break immersion.

All in all, this is a game you're not going to want to miss.

I beta-tested this game a few months ago. My name's in the credits. You may wish to take this review with a grain of salt.

Regardless, Linelight is an exercise in minimalism. Everything takes place on lines. There are no controls besides moving, and two others (to be revealed elsewhere in the game). How many puzzles, then, could someone possibly squeeze out of it?

About 300.

Oh right, you want to know more about the mechanics. As you can see in the screenshots and trailer, there are switches that move lines, switches that open doors, keys that open doors, enemies (some only move when you do, some move to the beat of the music, and some repeat your previous movements), spools that allow your line to become longer (so that it can press down multiple switches, among other things), and... well, not too much else actually.

Yet throughout all this, there is definitely a whole ton of ideas that Brett Taylor has incorporated; he's really covered all the bases with these puzzles. Most puzzles illustrate a neat consequence of the rules (some are "reprises", if you will), so there's not very much wasted space. And for most of these puzzles, there is really nothing quite like them in other games. Using a switch to release an enemy, then getting the enemy to toggle the switch so that you can get to the end is something I don't think I've seen in any other game, yet it's one of the first few puzzles in this game. (It's also Brett's favourite puzzle in the game, if I recall correctly).

Note also the amount of polish evident in the game. There is a very abstract nonverbal narrative involving helping other lines through problems (as opposed to the game being just a bunch of line puzzles, which is what some people who haven't played The Witness think of it). The soundtrack is spectacular and catchy (it's still floating around my head after all this time), and enhanced by the subtle percussion that the enemies add. The graphical effects upon entering a level, collecting a star, and so on, just add that tiny bit of prettiness that says "Yes, the developer put actual effort into this game. Unlike Flow Match or Rolling Shapes.". (And yes, I will be slagging off both of those games in every single review I post on Steam later. Because those two deserve it.) For a one-and-a-half-year one-person project, this is stunningly top-quality. (Unlike Flow Match, which was also a one-and-a-half-year one-person project, and was a complete piece of garbage that I managed to outdo in a single month.)

Some puzzles are a little finicky, but other than that, I honestly can't see any fault with this game. This is a strong Puzzle Game Of The Year 2017 contender. Or at least, it would be if I gave out game awards.

Linelight·❤

知道linelight是因为女流的直播录像。

“他们都慢慢离开了，还是只剩下我一个人……不过真好，还有你们……”嗯，刹那间被这句哀伤又怀柔的解说打动了。【女流真的很棒，爱女流！

自己打开游戏体味的瞬间——蔚蓝且梦幻的光晕，灵动而跳跃的节奏，夺目又琉璃的光线，一场华丽缤纷的盛大冒险就此展开，沿着婉转流动的光平滑移动，解开袖珍迷你电路图一样的关卡，碰触邂逅的粲然星眸……每一步都在跟着感觉，朝更远的地方进发。

起初蹒跚学步踽踽独行，一条轻盈活泼的光线无所畏惧地肆意徜徉，再后来你碰壁遭遇禁忌，碰触了高压和激战，渐渐学习起技能，有所长进，和不同的光线周旋竞技；运用思考的逻辑，思考解决的原理；你发现敌人不再永久的对立，有时和你肩并肩同舟共济；你懂得了迂回和迁就，明白了赞扬和给予；你尝遍了失败和大意，明白了取舍和维系；你复盘自己的道路，重逢着相似的搏击；……无数次地汇聚，无需多言的欢喜，天衣无缝的配比，畅游无阻的天地，美到窒息的诗情画意，不能言传只能会意……还有最最难以割舍的分离和深谙世事的孤寂……

这游戏到底是什么呢？明明没有台词和剧情，我却经历了浓墨重彩的好戏；明明只有光影和线段，我却体会了冷暖人生，刻骨铭心，醍醐灌顶，幡然悟醒。

很久没有那么安静地思索，沉浸在自己的世界里，放佛把很久以来杂乱的心绪抚平……大哭出来。真的很感谢。

太爱这个游戏，感谢linelight，感谢游戏带给我的鼓舞和勇气，那些欢乐和泪水，比心。

38995928.review: Linelight is a refreshing puzzle game that uses relatively simple mechanics to make many clever levels. The music is great - upbeat and catchy, and combined with the clean visuals sets a wonderful mood for the game that makes the game very enjoyable to play. The levels are a great difficulty, challenging enough to make them satisfying to solve, yet not difficult to the point you want to quit. Many of the levels can be passed over if desired and you can come back and return to them later. Each world has a set of more difficult challenges that are hidden off the main track to provide further challenge once you've played through the game. Some puzzles rely on timing and movement which is utilized well, but may be offputting for some people. It took me over 9 hours to complete everything, which with the unique gameplay makes it well worth the price.

你一个人行走在蜿蜒崎岖的道路上，追寻着光的照亮。在这你遇到许多人，他们会是你的好朋友也会是你的竞争对手，他们会拉你一把，也会推你一手，但你勇敢前行的毅力与才智终究会让所有险境化为乌有。当初遇到过的各种人造就了如今的你，你发现，路始终要一个人走下去，每个人都是过客，无论他们如何待你，最终还是会离开，只有坚定地走下去。初心不负方得始终，你会得到你的光。

这是一个非常非常棒的解谜游戏，轻快的音乐简约的画面，美丽而耀眼的光线。刚开始的关卡非常容易，很快速就能上手，但逐渐难度会增加，有时卡关，思维定在一个点上怎么也过不去，这种时候我就是下线休息了23333再次上线换个思路你会惊讶“咦！这样也可以诶”。仅需要动动脑子其实困难并不那么难。他是一个有节奏感的游戏，有些关卡我总需要默念一二一二这样一步步过去，看起来有点傻，但对我这种不太灵光手还挺残的人很管用。在游戏里有很多种不同的光线，很多时候通关都得要他们的帮助，他们偶尔是你的伙伴偶尔是你的敌人，会共同前进也会阻止你向前，结果往往是看你怎么走怎么操控。

我是一个比较容易放弃的人，但在这个游戏里受到的挫折却没有令我沮丧，反而愈挫愈勇，总感觉是里面的BGM太好听所以才有这种死也要通关的毅力？（其实游戏并不难！）

原价购买的时候我还有点嫌贵，但现在我要给个大大的好评，他值得这个价钱！他真的是一款非常非常非常非常棒的解谜游戏！

This is definitely the kind of game whose trailer I would normally gloss right over and never think twice about. But, I bought it, and played it, and loved it.

This game has heart, and polish, and is just all-around excellent.

There are 8 worlds, each with a different mechanic (well, the last two worlds let the mechanics play together). Each world introduces a mechanic's idea, lets you get familiar with it, then asks you to think about using it a few different ways. Just enough balance between fun and clever without tedious repeats of the same idea just to stretch things out.

Each world has its own final act, and each one is gorgeous. There is a lot of very smart orchestration, lovely, perfectly fitted music, and truly compelling puzzles.

This is a gem I'd rank near Thomas Was Alone, VVVVVV, or Limbo. It is absolutely satisfying from start to finish.
